Design with advanced ceramics for structural, thermal, electrical, piezoelectric, chemical, catalytic, and wear applications. Fundamental structure-property relationships underlying thermal shock, mechanical strength and fracture toughness, Weibull modulus and reliability, piezo-, thermo and optoelectric behaviour, corrosion, wear/abrasion, photocatalysis. Case Studies in design and performance of ceramic materials and products.


Oxide and non-oxide advanced ceramics, design parameters, structure/microstructure- processing-properties relations, thermal properties and materials, chemical (corrosion) properties and materials, mechanical properties and materials, thermomechanical properties and materials, tribological properties and materials, electromechanical properties and materials, magnetic properties and materials, electrical properties and materials, and optoelectronic properties and materials.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"cec60db3db791c50eb6b147a3a96199f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"35","description":"

Mechanical, tribological, thermal, thermomechanical, chemical, nuclear and biological properties

Feedback: Students will receive their final mark.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b5c60db3db791c50eb6b147a3a961999","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f1c60db3db791c50eb6b147a3a96199c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"21c60db3db791c50eb6b147a3a961973","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-term exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Electrical, electromechanical, magnetic and optoelectronic properties, and materials

Feedback: Students will receive their marked exams indicating what questions were answered correctly and incorrectly. Overall comments and worked solutions may be provided to the class.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"79c60db3db791c50eb6b147a3a961996","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b5c60db3db791c50eb6b147a3a961999","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f1c60db3db791c50eb6b147a3a96199c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"69c60db3db791c50eb6b147a3a961977","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Students are required to undertake a task involving the application of functional properties including electrical, electronic, optical and magnetic properties covered in Weeks 1-4. It is designed to introduce the students to a broader range of functionalities and practical applications of state-of-the-art ceramics and related materials and to provide formative assessment of the learning process

Feedback will be given two weeks after submission of the assignment and take the form of the mark for the assignment, overall comments on how the class performed, any common areas that were not answered correctly. Additionally, personal feedback and how each student performed may be given.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b5c60db3db791c50eb6b147a3a961999","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f1c60db3db791c50eb6b147a3a96199c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a1c60db3db791c50eb6b147a3a96197c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

Students will be required to conduct research on a topic involving materials, properties, performance, of advanced ceramic products in terms of their mechanical / tribological / thermal / thermomechanical / corrosion / nuclear/ biological properties for further learning on current and relevant applications and issues related to the properties and processing of these materials and formative assessment of the learning process

Feedback will be given two weeks after submission of the assignment and take the form of the mark for the assignment, overall comments on how the class performed, any common areas that were not answered correctly. Additionally, personal feedback and how each student performed may be given.

honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"MATS4003","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATS4003 - Process Metallurgy Advanced","description":"

Reaction rate and expressions for different reaction systems; kinetics and thermodynamics of metallurgical reactions; heat balance and mass balance of chemical reactors; batch and semibatch reactors; plug flow reactors (gas reactants in most metallurgical processes); mixed tank reactors (smelting, steel refining); catalytic reactions Heterogeneous reactions; fixed bed reactors (stack leaching processes); fluidised bed reactors (fluid bed roasting, alternative ironmaking technologies); moving bed reactors (blast furnace, Corex process).
Types of metallurgical reactors, batch and continuous, plug flow and well-mixed reactors. Tracer additions. Chemical performance of a metallurgical reactor. Principles of metallurgical reactor design. Major technologies in ferrous and non-ferrous metallurgy and their development.

contentlets.description:
Reaction rate and expressions for different reaction systems; kinetics and thermodynamics of metallurgical reactions; heat balance and mass balance of chemical reactors; batch and semibatch reactors; plug flow reactors (gas reactants in most metallurgical processes); mixed tank reactors (smelting, steel refining); catalytic reactions Heterogeneous reactions; fixed bed reactors (stack leaching processes); fluidised bed reactors (fluid bed roasting, alternative ironmaking technologies); moving bed reactors (blast furnace, Corex process).
Types of metallurgical reactors, batch and continuous, plug flow and well-mixed reactors. Tracer additions. Chemical performance of a metallurgical reactor. Principles of metallurgical reactor design. Major technologies in ferrous and non-ferrous metallurgy and their development.

Materials failure case study.  Students will research and reports on a historic materials failure that caused a major industrial disruption and resulted in legal proceedings.  They will prepare a report and a short presentation summarising the case study.

Feedback will be given two weeks after submission of the assignment and take the form of the mark for the assignment, overall comments on how the class performed, any common areas that were not answered correctly. Additionally, personal feedback and how each student performed may be given.

The mid-term exam will be held in class and cover the topics taught in weeks 1-6

Students will receive their marked exams indicating what questions were answered correctly and incorrectly. Overall comments and worked solutions may be provided to the class.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5e7bea6bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a961920","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d67bea6bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a961926","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"027baa6bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619ff","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory report","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Detailed investigation of fracture surfaces.  Students will use laboratory methods to investigate the fracture surface of a material failure to understand its origins and write a detailed report.

Feedback: Students will receive their mark and individualised feedback on the areas they excelled at and which areas of the reports that were not answered correctly. Feedback will be provided through Moodle, two weeks after submission.

Feedback: Students will receive their final mark.

The course deals with two important categories of advanced materials, namely functional materials and composite materials.


The functional materials part will focus on the following topics:  Basic principles of semiconductors and their fabrication processes for electronic devices (single crystal growth, implantation, lithography, etching and thin film growth), sources of failure; design and characteristics of functional materials for supercapacitors and batteries, biosensors, metal-organic frameworks, design of nanostructured functional materials in different configuration (3D,2D, and 1D) and for different applications (supercapacitors, batteries, fuel cells, sensors, catalysts, photovoltaics)


The composite materials part will focus on the following topics:  Properties of fibre reinforced polymer matrix composites, metal matrix composites, ceramic matrix composites; fibres, matrices and fibre/matrix interface; mechanical behaviour of fibre reinforced composites; fracture and durability of composites; composite structure and design; composite manufacture and recycling.

contentlets.description:
The course deals with two important categories of advanced materials, namely functional materials and composite materials.

The functional materials part will focus on the following topics:  Basic principles of semiconductors and their fabrication processes for electronic devices (single crystal growth, implantation, lithography, etching and thin film growth), sources of failure; design and characteristics of functional materials for supercapacitors and batteries, biosensors, metal-organic frameworks, design of nanostructured functional materials in different configuration (3D,2D, and 1D) and for different applications (supercapacitors, batteries, fuel cells, sensors, catalysts, photovoltaics)

The composite materials part will focus on the following topics:  Properties of fibre reinforced polymer matrix composites, metal matrix composites, ceramic matrix composites; fibres, matrices and fibre/matrix interface; mechanical behaviour of fibre reinforced composites; fracture and durability of composites; composite structure and design; composite manufacture and recycling.
contentlets.title: Composites and Functional Materials

The course is divided into four sections:


  • Advances in Polymer Synthesis: synthetic polymers/copolymers, biopolymers and blending routes to produce polymers with enhanced functionalities
  • Polymer Physics and Bulk Properties: rheology: dilute, concentrated polymer solutions and melt polymers; rubber elasticity theory; gelation phenomena; elastic deformation and viscoelasticity; electric and optical properties; surfaces and interfaces; degradation modes of polymers
  • Functional polymers: design and application of advanced polymers, including but not limited to polymers in optoelectronics, solar technology, and medicine.
  • Lab component: 3 laboratories related to degradation of polymers, mass loss, structural, optical and chemical characterisation; 3 laboratories related to network and gelation concepts.

Laboratories will be related to degradation of polymers structural, optical and chemical characterisation, network and gelation concepts.

2 hr duration it will cover the topics taught in weeks 6-10

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2ca685b3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619cb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a0a685b3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619c6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"eca685b3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"54a685b3db791c50eb6b147a3a96196c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Design project that runs over the duration of the course - students will be required to choose a polymer and a product made from it. The group assignment should include synthesis of the polymer, fabrication and processing of the product, its degradation and mechanical properties, and input on how to improve the product design.  Their designs and characterisation will be based on the content taught in class. Students will hand in a report in week 4 to assess their progress. The designed product and a final report will be due in week 9.

contentlets.description:
The course is divided into four sections:

  • Advances in Polymer Synthesis: synthetic polymers/copolymers, biopolymers and blending routes to produce polymers with enhanced functionalities
  • Polymer Physics and Bulk Properties: rheology: dilute, concentrated polymer solutions and melt polymers; rubber elasticity theory; gelation phenomena; elastic deformation and viscoelasticity; electric and optical properties; surfaces and interfaces; degradation modes of polymers
  • Functional polymers: design and application of advanced polymers, including but not limited to polymers in optoelectronics, solar technology, and medicine.
  • Lab component: 3 laboratories related to degradation of polymers, mass loss, structural, optical and chemical characterisation; 3 laboratories related to network and gelation concepts.

Corrosion Control","assoc_campus":null,"assoc_url":"/undergraduate/courses/2021/MATS1223","assoc_class":"Course","assoc_award_titles":null,"assoc_state":"inactive","assoc_award_single":"","assoc_code":"MATS1223","assoc_class_translated_subjects":"Course","assoc_faculty":"Faculty of Science","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"MATS4007 - Engineered Surfaces to Resist Corrosion and Wear","description":"

Degradation of engineering materials occurs in all applications through corrosion and wear. This advanced level course teaches students how to minimise and control the rate at which this occurs to extend the lifespan of engineered components. The course is taught through lecture and laboratories and cover three main areas:


Surface Engineering: Students will learn about the purpose of engineered surfaces to increase the lifespan of materials with a focus on the hardening of steel and the common methods used in industry to protect different materials.


Wear: Wear occurs in many engineering applications; this course will inform students of the economic reasons for wear resistant materials and how other material properties affect the wear resistance. To understand the complex wear system the fundamental models of wear will be taught through the wholistic tribological approach.


Corrosion and control: Corrosion occurs in several ways, students will learn the causes of each type of corrosion and prevent corrosion from happening and reduce the rate at which corrosion occurs in established systems.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a3c68db3db791c50eb6b147a3a96190e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"4 Assignments","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Four short assignments on the following topics:

  1. Corrosion 1 (5%)
  2. Corrosion 2 (5%)
  3. Surface treatment (10%)
  4. Wear (10%)

Feedback will be given two weeks after submission of the assignment and take the form of the mark for the assignment, overall comments on how the class performed, any common areas that were not answered correctly. Additionally, personal feedback and how each student performed may be given.

The in-class exam will cover the topics taught in weeks 1-5.

Feedback: Students will receive their final mark

Lab 1 can be performed by each student on their own.
Lab 2 the students will be divided into groups of 5 ~ 6, depending on the number of students in the class. Details of the labs will be provided in a later stage.

Students will receive their mark and individualised feedback on the areas they excelled at and which areas of the reports that were not answered correctly. Feedback will be provided through Moodle, two weeks after submission.

contentlets.description:
Degradation of engineering materials occurs in all applications through corrosion and wear. This advanced level course teaches students how to minimise and control the rate at which this occurs to extend the lifespan of engineered components. The course is taught through lecture and laboratories and cover three main areas:

Surface Engineering: Students will learn about the purpose of engineered surfaces to increase the lifespan of materials with a focus on the hardening of steel and the common methods used in industry to protect different materials.

Wear: Wear occurs in many engineering applications; this course will inform students of the economic reasons for wear resistant materials and how other material properties affect the wear resistance. To understand the complex wear system the fundamental models of wear will be taught through the wholistic tribological approach.

Corrosion and control: Corrosion occurs in several ways, students will learn the causes of each type of corrosion and prevent corrosion from happening and reduce the rate at which corrosion occurs in established systems.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"MATS4008","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATS4008 - Materials Engineering Project","description":"

An experimental or technical investigation or design related to some aspects of materials engineering in the specific discipline (ceramic engineering, metallurgical engineering or materials engineering).

Note: This course is taken twice for a total of 12UoC


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3ae42ae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961994","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Literature Survey Submission","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"","description":"

Students are required to submit a polished copy of their completed Literature Survey and coversheet signed by their supervisor that it is complete and of a satisfactory standard. Students are to receive formative feedback from their supervisor prior to submission and submit with the accompanying feedback form.

The Introduction and Literature Survey chapters are submitted in Term 1 and marked by the supervisor to provide formative assessment and feedback to the student.  The completed thesis is graded by the student's supervisor and another independent academic from the School following submission at the end of Term 2.  The name of the independent grading academic is not given to the student.  The average of the above marks is reported to the student in writing (via Moodle) following the release of results at the end of Term 2.  All feedback and discussion concerning the marked work is provided by the student's supervisor.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2ae42ae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961985","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"2ee42ae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961990","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"66e42ae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961988","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a2e42ae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a96198b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"eee42ae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a96198d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"12e42ae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961962","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project management plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"5","description":"

Students are required to submit a project management plan for the Honours Project covering the following elements:  executive summary describing the project to be undertaken and its scope; goals of the project; detailed project planning; resource allocation; budgeting and cost estimation; scheduling; monitoring and project control; project auditing; and project termination.

The assignment is marked by the course coordinator using a standardised rubric.  Written feedback is given by the course coordinator and verbal feedback is given by the student's supervisor. Marks are given at the end of the project averaged over the two Terms. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"2ee42ae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961990","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"66e42ae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961988","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a2e42ae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a96198b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1ae42ae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a96195d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Thesis Progress Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"","description":"

Students are required to submit a Thesis Progress Report signed by student and supervisor outlining progress, delays against the project plan and anticipated tasks remaining.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a2e42ae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a96198b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"eee42ae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a96198d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1ae42ae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961966","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar Presentation 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"12","description":"

Students are required to give a formal seminar presentation (17 minutes) that presents the outcomes of the Honours project and their analysis and discussion, and major conclusions.  The seminar presentation is graded by the student's supervisor, the course coordinator, and one independent academic from the School.

Verbal feedback immediately following the seminar presentation is provided by the course coordinator and the supervisor; formal written feedback as per the above marking criteria is provided to the student within 1 week of the presentation. Marks are given at the end of the project averaged over the two Terms. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2ae42ae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961985","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a2e42ae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a96198b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"eee42ae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a96198d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"52e42ae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a96196b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Honours Thesis Dissertation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"6","weighting":"75","description":"

The Honours thesis dissertation is the major piece of written work submitted at the end of the 12UOC research project. An Honours thesis dissertation in Materials Science and Engineering is typically 80 pages which is marked by the supervisor and two nominated independent academic assessors using a standardised rubric for all theses.

The Introduction and Literature Survey chapters are submitted in Term 1 and marked by the supervisor to provide formative assessment and feedback to the student.  The completed thesis is graded by the student's supervisor and another independent academic from the School following submission at the end of Term 2.  The name of the independent grading academic is not given to the student.  The average of the above marks is reported to the student in writing (via Moodle) following the release of results at the end of Term 2.  All feedback and discussion concerning the marked work is provided by the student's supervisor. Marks are given at the end of the project averaged over the two Terms.

At the end of T1, students are required to give a seminar presentation (12 minutes) based on their written literature survey and project proposal, and answer questions on their presentation. Each seminar is graded by the student's supervisor, the course coordinator, and one independent academic from the School.

Verbal feedback immediately following the seminar presentation is provided by the course coordinator and the supervisor; formal written feedback as per the above marking criteria is provided to the student within 1 week of the presentation. Marks are given at the end of the project averaged over the two Terms.

contentlets.description:
An experimental or technical investigation or design related to some aspects of materials engineering in the specific discipline (ceramic engineering, metallurgical engineering or materials engineering).

Note: This course is taken twice for a total of 12UoC

In either case a final grade is withheld until the final course is completed."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATS4100 - Materials Engineering Project","description":"

A self-directed experimental research or design-based project to apply, contextualise, and integrate fundamental scientific/engineering concepts learnt throughout the Materials Science and Engineering undergraduate program.  Students will develop advanced disciplinary knowledge and will apply this to problem solving in the chosen topic area. Students will develop and practice high-level skills in critical thinking, project management, safety consideration and risk management, data collection and analysis, problem solving, and technical communication.


Note: this course is 18 UOC in total: 6 UOC per term over three terms.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"296245f7db391c50eb6b147a3a96197b","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar Presentation 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"12","description":"

Description:
Students are required to give a formal seminar presentation (20 minutes) that presents the outcomes of the Honours project and their analysis and discussion, and major conclusions.  The seminar presentation is graded by the student's supervisor, the course coordinator, and one independent academic from the School.

Students are required to give a seminar presentation (20 minutes) based on their written literature survey and proposal, and answer questions on their presentation.

Assessment:

Each seminar is graded by the student's supervisor, the course coordinator, and one independent academic from the School using a standardised rubric to assess the following elements:

Technical Content:  technical standard, amount and adequacy of material, depth of coverage, interest of the material presented, ability to answer questions.

Quality of Presentation:  Structure – organisation of material, balance of the material presented, logic and orderliness of material, focus on important points, clarity of presentation.  Verbal Delivery – pace, pronunciation and enunciation, voice modulation, avoidance of extraneous vocal mannerisms.  Physical Delivery – control of nervousness, eye contact with audience, effective use of body movement, avoidance of extraneous physical mannerisms.

Visual Impression: Visual Aids – pace of presentation, interest and effectiveness of visual aids, pertinence of visual aids to the presentation, legibility and quality of visual aids.  Appearance – posture and deportment of speaker

Overall Impression

Feedback:

Verbal feedback immediately following the seminar presentation is provided by the course coordinator and the supervisor; formal written feedback as per the above marking criteria is provided to the student within 1 week of the presentation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"196245f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961968","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"516245f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d96245f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961965","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"096245f7db391c50eb6b147a3a96193c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Honours Thesis Dissertation","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"75","description":"

Description:
The Honours thesis dissertation is the major piece of written work submitted at the end of the 18UOC research project.  An Honours thesis dissertation in Materials Science and Engineering is typically 80 pages which is marked by the supervisor and two nominated independent academic assessors using a standardised rubric for all theses.

Assessment:

The assignment is marked using a standardised rubric with marks being awarded for the following elements:

1.  Quality of Abstract; English expression and spelling; Thesis formatting & general impression.

2.  Introduction and Literature Review Chapters:  level of presentation, extent and relevance; critical assessment of the literature; referencing; establishment of project aims.

3.  Experimental Procedure:  completeness and clarity of experimental outline.

4.  Results/Work Effort:  amount of experimental work done, completeness of study, quality, logic and organisation of experiments, use of graphs, figures and tables to summarise results.

5.  Discussion and Conclusions:  level of understanding, interpretation of results and sophistication of analysis, handling and identification of errors, comparison with other data, achievements with respect to project aims.

Feedback:

The Introduction and Literature Review chapters are submitted in Term 1 and marked by the supervisor to provide formative assessment and feedback to the student.  The completed thesis is graded by graded by the student's supervisor and two independent academics from the School following submission at the end of Term 3.  The names of the two independent academics are not given to the student.  The average of the above marks are reported to the student in writing (via Moodle) following the release of results at the end of Term 3.  All feedback and discussion concerning the marked work is provided by the student's supervisor.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"196245f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961968","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"516245f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"656245f7db391c50eb6b147a3a96196b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9d6245f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961962","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d96245f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961965","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"416245f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961941","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar Presentation 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"8","description":"

Description:

At the end of T1, students are required to give a seminar presentation (20 minutes) based on their written literature survey and project proposal, and answer questions on their presentation. Each seminar is graded by the student's supervisor, the course coordinator, and one independent academic from the School.

Assessment:

Each seminar is graded by the student's supervisor, the course coordinator, and one independent academic from the School using a standardised rubric to assess the following elements:

Technical Content:  technical standard, amount and adequacy of material, depth of coverage, interest of the material presented, ability to answer questions.

Quality of Presentation:  Structure – organisation of material, balance of the material presented, logic and orderliness of material, focus on important points, clarity of presentation.  Verbal Delivery – pace, pronunciation and enunciation, voice modulation, avoidance of extraneous vocal mannerisms.  Physical Delivery – control of nervousness, eye contact with audience, effective use of body movement, avoidance of extraneous physical mannerisms.

Visual Impression: Visual Aids – pace of presentation, interest and effectiveness of visual aids, pertinence of visual aids to the presentation, legibility and quality of visual aids.  Appearance – posture and deportment of speaker

Overall Impression

Feedback:

Verbal feedback immediately following the seminar presentation is provided by the course coordinator and the supervisor; formal written feedback as per the above marking criteria is provided to the student within 1 week of the presentation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"196245f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961968","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"516245f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d96245f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961965","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"896245f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961945","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Management Plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"5","description":"

Description:
The aim of this assignment is to develop a project management plan for the Honours Project covering the following elements:  executive summary describing the project to be undertaken and its scope; goals of the project; detailed project planning; resource allocation; budgeting and cost estimation; scheduling; monitoring and project control; project auditing; and project termination.

Assessment and Feedback: 
The assignment is marked by the course coordinator using a standardised rubric.  Written feedback is given by the course coordinator and verbal feedback is given by the student's supervisor.

contentlets.keywords: materials science and engineering,materials honours project,materials engineering project
contentlets.description:
A self-directed experimental research or design-based project to apply, contextualise, and integrate fundamental scientific/engineering concepts learnt throughout the Materials Science and Engineering undergraduate program.  Students will develop advanced disciplinary knowledge and will apply this to problem solving in the chosen topic area. Students will develop and practice high-level skills in critical thinking, project management, safety consideration and risk management, data collection and analysis, problem solving, and technical communication.

Note: this course is 18 UOC in total: 6 UOC per term over three terms.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATS4500 - Honours Project A","description":"

This course is designed for students undertaking a full-time Honours year in Programs 4500 and 3972 in the School of Materials Science and Engineering, run over two semesters.  Materials Science Honours enables students to undertake a supervised Research Project under the direction of an academic staff member in the School, where the project introduces students to research and places emphasis on advanced disciplinary knowledge.  Over the course of the Honours project the student will gain experience in the use of specialised research techniques relevant to their chosen area, critical thinking, data collection and analysis, problem solving and scientific communication.  Assessment tasks include the submission of a Research Thesis based on substantial independent research activity.


This course is only available to students enrolled in the School of Materials Science and Engineering Honours Program, and the School's Honours Coordinator must approve enrolment.  Students undertaking Honours full-time will enrol in MATS4500 (along with MATS4503 and MATS4504) in their first semester then MATS4501 in their second semester.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2ae1f4fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619fc","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar Presentation S2","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

At the end of S2, students give a formal seminar which presents the outcomes of the Honours project and their analysis and discussion, and major conclusions.  The duration of the presentation is up to 20 minutes and is open the staff and students of the School.  The seminar is graded by academics from the School in the audience.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"22e1f4fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619f6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5ae1f4fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619bd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Thesis","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

The thesis is the major piece of work submitted at the end of the 36 UOC research project (MATS4500 (12UOC) + MATS4501 (24UOC)).   A Materials Honours thesis typically is 80 pages.  It is marked by three nominated academic assessors and the supervisor using a standardised rubric for all theses.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"22e1f4fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619f6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6ae1f4fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619ed","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"6ee1f4fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619f8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a6e1f4fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e2e1f4fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619f3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"92e1f4fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619c2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Oral Examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

A formal oral examination of the research thesis is conducted following submission of the written thesis at the end of the second semester.  The examination pertains to all aspects of the research work.  It is attended by three nominated academic assessors and the supervisor but is closed to the public.  The assessment uses a standard rubric for evaluating the research work.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"22e1f4fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619f6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"92e1f4fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619d3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar Presentation S1","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

In S1, students give a formal seminar which outlines the proposal for the project including a statement of the project objectives established from the literature survey, the main methodologies to be employed in the research, and a management plan of the entire Honours project. The duration of the presentation is up to 20 minutes and is open the staff and students of the School.  The seminar is graded by academics from the School in the audience.

honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"MATS4501","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"24 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATS4501 - Honours Project B","description":"

This course is designed for students undertaking a full-time Honours year in Programs 4500 and 3972 in the School of Materials Science and Engineering, run over two semesters. Materials Science Honours enables students to undertake a supervised Research Project under the direction of an academic staff member in the School, where the project introduces students to research and places emphasis on advanced disciplinary knowledge. Over the course of the Honours project the student will gain experience in the use of specialised research techniques relevant to their chosen area, critical thinking, data collection and analysis, problem solving and scientific communication. Assessment tasks include the submission of a Research Thesis based on substantial independent research activity.


This course is only available to students enrolled in the School of Materials Science and Engineering Honours Program, and the School's Honours Coordinator must approve enrolment.  Students undertaking Honours full-time will enrol in MATS4500 (along with MATS4503 and MATS4504) in their first semester then MATS4501 in their second semester.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e7e138fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a96195c","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar Presentation S1","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

In S1, students give a formal seminar which outlines the proposal for the project including a statement of the project objectives established from the literature survey, the main methodologies to be employed in the research, and a management plan of the entire Honours project. The duration of the presentation is up to 20 minutes and is open the staff and students of the School.  The seminar is graded by academics from the School in the audience.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1be138fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a96194d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"1fe138fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961958","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"57e138fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"93e138fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961953","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"dfe138fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961955","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0be138fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a96193f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar Presentation S2","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

At the end of S2, students give a formal seminar which presents the outcomes of the Honours project and their analysis and discussion, and major conclusions.  The duration of the presentation is up to 20 minutes and is open the staff and students of the School.  The seminar is graded by academics from the School in the audience.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1be138fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a96194d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"1fe138fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961958","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"57e138fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"93e138fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961953","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"dfe138fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961955","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"43e138fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961944","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Thesis","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"60","description":"

The thesis is the major piece of work submitted at the end of the 36 UOC research project (MATS4500 (12UOC) + MATS4501 (24UOC)).   A Materials Honours thesis typically is 80 pages.  It is marked by three nominated academic assessors and the supervisor using a standardised rubric for all theses.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1be138fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a96194d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"1fe138fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961958","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"57e138fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"93e138fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961953","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"dfe138fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961955","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"87e138fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961936","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Oral Examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

A formal oral examination of the research thesis is conducted following submission of the written thesis at the end of the second semester.  The examination pertains to all aspects of the research work.  It is attended by three nominated academic assessors and the supervisor but is closed to the public.  The assessment uses a standard rubric for evaluating the research work.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"MATS4503","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATS4503 - Professional Skills","description":"

This course provides students with formal training in professional communication, writing skills, project planning, data analysis, intellectual property, risk management, and workplace health and safety.  These skills directly underpin the Materials Science Honours Project (MATS4505) and provide essential generic skills for any science graduate.  The course is only available to students enrolled in the School of Materials Science and Engineering Honours Program, and must be taken in a student's first term of Honours in conjunction with a Science Honours research project in the School of Materials Science and Engineering. The School's Honours Coordinator must approve enrolment.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f4e7a17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961954","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Workplace Health and Safety / Ethics Quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will also need to demonstrate competence in workplace health and safety and ethics relevant to professional practice as a materials scientist.

  • School WHS Induction Session
  • UNSW Online Safety for Students Course
  • Training sessions and WHS Documentation specific to their experimental work.

Satisfactory completion of online training; written WHS documents discussed with the supervisor.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"3ce7a17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"bce7a17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96193b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"28e7a17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961926","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Data Analysis Report and Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Part 1: Students are required to research and give a short formal presentation on a topic allocated by the lecturer.  The presentation will be critiqued by the lecturer and by students in the audience. The presentation gives students the opportunity to practice giving a formal presentation utilising the skills and techniques taught in class and will provide constructive advice to students on ways to improve their public speaking.

Part 2: Students are required to systematically analyse the introduction, experimental procedure, and results of a published experiment provided by the lecturer. Students will: critique the introduction and rationale of the experiment; comment on the experimental designed used in the work; identify trends and their significance in the experimental data, and formulate a coherent discussion of the results as well as a conclusion. Following submission of their report, students will be given opportunity to compare their work with that actually published for the original work. This assessment task will also give student opportunity to practice writing skills taught in the course.

Feedback:
Presentation: Immediate feedback following the presentation. Formal marking criteria to assess presentation.
Data Analysis report: Written marking and comments from lecturer as per rubric

 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"38e7a17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961941","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"bce7a17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96193b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"60e7a17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96192b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Curriculum Vitae","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

In consultation with UNSW Careers & Employment, students are to revise their resume and to prepare a cover letter to apply (real or fictitiously) for a real position recently advertised. Students will be required to attend a 20-minute interview with UNSW Careers & Employment during session (organised outside class).

Feedback: Written marking and comments from lecturer as per rubric. Formal feedback from UNSW Careers & Employment.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"38e7a17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961941","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"60e7a17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961939","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"bce7a17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96193b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f8e7a17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96193e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a8e7a17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96192f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Management Plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Students are required to formulate a project management plan for the research project detailing the following planning aspects of the project: scope and major objectives, human-equipment-consumable resources needed, project milestones and schedule, and auditing process.

Feedback: Marked report is returned to students and discussed with supervisor.

contentlets.description: This course provides students with formal training in professional communication, writing skills, project planning, data analysis, intellectual property, risk management, and workplace health and safety.  These skills directly underpin the Materials Science Honours Project (MATS4505) and provide essential generic skills for any science graduate.  The course is only available to students enrolled in the School of Materials Science and Engineering Honours Program, and must be taken in a student's first term of Honours in conjunction with a Science Honours research project in the School of Materials Science and Engineering. The School's Honours Coordinator must approve enrolment.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"MATS4504","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATS4504 - Research Training","description":"

This course provides an essential introduction to Honours for Science students undertaking a full-time Honours program in the School of Materials Science and Engineering.   The course results in a written research proposal providing an account of relevant scientific literature and a description of the research work expected to be undertaken during the Honours program.  The focus of the research proposal is decided in consultation with the student's Honours Supervisor and is related to the topic area of the research project.  Students will also present a short seminar based on their proposal.  Other required research training, including relevant workplace health and safety inductions and additional instruction on topics including preparation of research proposals, and ethical practice, complements this course.


The course is only available to students enrolled in the School of Materials Science and Engineering Honours Program, and must be taken in a student's first semester of Honours in conjunction with a Science Honours research project in the School of Materials Science and Engineering.  The School's Honours Coordinator must approve enrolment.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"08f138fbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619d8","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"70","description":"

The project proposal is the major piece of work submitted for this 6 UOC introductory Honours course.  It will consist of a review of relevant literature and a proposal of work to be carried out during the Honours year.

Students are required to give a short seminar based on their written literature survey and proposal, and answer questions on their presentation.  The seminar is graded by academics from the School in the audience.

In either case a final grade is withheld until the final course is completed."}],"credit_points_header":"12 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATS4505 - Materials Science Honours Project","description":"

This course is designed for students undertaking a full-time Honours year in Programs 4500 and 3962 in the School of Materials Science and Engineering, run over three terms.  Materials Science Honours enables students to undertake a supervised Research Project under the direction of an academic staff member in the School, where the project introduces students to research and places emphasis on advanced disciplinary knowledge.  Over the course of the Honours project the student will gain experience in the use of specialised research techniques relevant to their chosen area, critical thinking, data collection and analysis, problem solving and scientific communication.  Assessment tasks include the submission of a Research Thesis based on substantial independent research activity.


This course is only available to students enrolled in the School of Materials Science and Engineering Honours Program, and the School's Honours Coordinator must approve enrolment. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"490245b7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b2","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar Presentation 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

At the end of their project, students give a formal seminar that presents the outcomes of the Honours project, their analysis and discussion, and major conclusions. The duration of the presentation is up to 20 minutes and is open the staff and students of the School. The seminar is graded by academics from the School in the audience.

Feedback: Immediate verbal feedback following presentation; formal written marking criteria to assess presentation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"010245b7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ac","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"200245b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961991","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Thesis","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

The thesis is the major piece of work submitted at the end of the 36 UOC research project. A Materials Honours thesis typically is 80 pages. It is marked by three nominated academic assessors and the supervisor using a standardised rubric for all theses.

Feedback: Marked thesis is returned to student and discussed with supervisor

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"010245b7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ac","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"4d0245b7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"780245b7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b40245b7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c10245b7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619a9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"680245b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961995","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Oral Examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

A formal oral examination of the research thesis is conducted following submission of the written thesis at the end of the third trimester. The examination pertains to all aspects of the research work. It is attended by three nominated academic assessors and the supervisor but is closed to the public. The assessment uses a standard rubric for evaluating the research work.

Feedback: Immediate verbal feedback following presentation; formal written marking criteria to assess presentation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"010245b7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ac","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b00245b7db391c50eb6b147a3a96199a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar Presentation 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Students give a formal seminar that outlines the proposal for the project, including a statement of the project objectives established from the literature survey, the main methodologies to be employed in the research, and a management plan of the entire Honours project. The duration of the presentation is up to 30 minutes and is open the staff and students of the School. The seminar is graded by academics from the School in the audience. (Total time 1 hr, 30mins presentation and 30mins questions)

Feedback: Immediate verbal feedback following presentation; formal written marking criteria to assess presentation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"010245b7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ac","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e40245b7db391c50eb6b147a3a96198c","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/MATS4505.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description:
This course is designed for students undertaking a full-time Honours year in Programs 4500 and 3962 in the School of Materials Science and Engineering, run over three terms.  Materials Science Honours enables students to undertake a supervised Research Project under the direction of an academic staff member in the School, where the project introduces students to research and places emphasis on advanced disciplinary knowledge.  Over the course of the Honours project the student will gain experience in the use of specialised research techniques relevant to their chosen area, critical thinking, data collection and analysis, problem solving and scientific communication.  Assessment tasks include the submission of a Research Thesis based on substantial independent research activity.

This course is only available to students enrolled in the School of Materials Science and Engineering Honours Program, and the School's Honours Coordinator must approve enrolment.

Students are required to submit a Thesis Progress Report signed by student and supervisor outlining progress, delays against the project plan and anticipated tasks remaining.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"12f4eae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961901","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d2f4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619fe","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0af4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619c3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Literature Survey Submission","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"","description":"

Students are required to submit a polished copy of their completed Literature Survey and coversheet signed by their supervisor that it is complete and of a satisfactory standard. Students are to receive formative feedback from their supervisor prior to submission and submit with the accompanying feedback form.

Feedback: The Introduction and Literature Survey chapters are submitted in Term 1 and marked by the supervisor to provide formative assessment and feedback to the student.  The completed thesis is graded by the student's supervisor and another independent academic from the School following submission at the end of Term 3.  The name of the independent grading academic is not given to the student.  The average of the above marks is reported to the student in writing (via Moodle) following the release of results at the end of Term 3.  All feedback and discussion concerning the marked work are provided by the student's supervisor.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"12f4eae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961901","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"42f4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619d6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5ef4eae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961903","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"9af4eae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961906","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d2f4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619fe","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"31f4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619bf","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar Presentation 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"8","description":"

At the end of T1, students are required to give a seminar presentation (12 minutes) based on their written literature survey and project proposal, and answer questions on their presentation. Each seminar is graded by the student's supervisor, the course coordinator, and one independent academic from the School.

Verbal feedback immediately following the seminar presentation is provided by the course coordinator and the supervisor; formal written feedback as per the above marking criteria is provided to the student within 1 week of the presentation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"12f4eae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961901","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"42f4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619d6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5ef4eae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961903","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"39f4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619a9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar Presentation 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"12","description":"

Students are required to give a formal seminar presentation (17 minutes) that presents the outcomes of the Honours project and their analysis and discussion, and major conclusions.  The seminar presentation is graded by the student's supervisor, the course coordinator, and one independent academic from the School.

Verbal feedback immediately following the seminar presentation is provided by the course coordinator and the supervisor; formal written feedback as per the above marking criteria is provided to the student within 1 week of the presentation.

Students are required to submit a project management plan for the Honours Project covering the following elements:  executive summary describing the project to be undertaken and its scope; goals of the project; detailed project planning; resource allocation; budgeting and cost estimation; scheduling; monitoring and project control; project auditing; and project termination.

Feedback: The assignment is marked by the course coordinator using a standardised rubric.  Written feedback is given by the course coordinator and verbal feedback is given by the student's supervisor. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"12f4eae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961901","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"9af4eae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961906","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d2f4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619fe","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"71f4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619ae","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Honours Thesis Dissertation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"6","weighting":"75","description":"

The Honours thesis dissertation is the major piece of written work submitted at the end of the 18UOC research project. An Honours thesis dissertation in Materials Science and Engineering is typically 80 pages which are marked by the supervisor and two nominated independent academic assessors using a standardised rubric for all theses.

Feedback: The Introduction and Literature Survey chapters are submitted in Term 1 and marked by the supervisor to provide formative assessment and feedback to the student.  The completed thesis is graded by the student's supervisor and another independent academic from the School following submission at the end of Term 3.  The name of the independent grading academic is not given to the student.  The average of the above marks is reported to the student in writing (via Moodle) following the release of results at the end of Term 3.  All feedback and discussion concerning the marked work is provided by the student's supervisor.

This is a 6 UOC supplementary course for students who have taken or are taking both MATS5001 and MATS5002 and wish to undertake an 18 UOC total thesis project.Note: for students who have not undertaken MATS5001 and MATS5002 please be aware that these courses may be taken as co-requisites with MATS5003.","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e5f4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a96196f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar Presentation 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"12","description":"

Students are required to give a formal seminar presentation (17 minutes) that presents the outcomes of the Honours project and their analysis and discussion, and major conclusions.  The seminar presentation is graded by the student's supervisor, the course coordinator, and one independent academic from the School.

Feedback: Verbal feedback immediately following the seminar presentation is provided by the course coordinator and the supervisor; formal written feedback as per the above marking criteria is provided to the student within 1 week of the presentation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"19f4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"91f4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961966","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"edf4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961968","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"19f4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961952","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Honours Thesis Dissertation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"6","weighting":"75","description":"

The Honours thesis dissertation is the major piece of written work submitted at the end of the 18UOC research project. An Honours thesis dissertation in Materials Science and Engineering is typically 80 pages which is marked by the supervisor and two nominated independent academic assessors using a standardised rubric for all theses.

Feedback: The Introduction and Literature Survey chapters are submitted in Term 1 and marked by the supervisor to provide formative assessment and feedback to the student.  The completed thesis is graded by the student's supervisor and another independent academic from the School following submission at the end of Term 3.  The name of the independent grading academic is not given to the student.  The average of the above marks is reported to the student in writing (via Moodle) following the release of results at the end of Term 3.  All feedback and discussion concerning the marked work is provided by the student's supervisor.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"19f4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"2df4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a96196b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"55f4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961963","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"91f4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961966","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"edf4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961968","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"51f4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961957","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar Presentation 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"8","description":"

At the end of T1, students are required to give a seminar presentation (12 minutes) based on their written literature survey and project proposal, and answer questions on their presentation. Each seminar is graded by the student's supervisor, the course coordinator, and one independent academic from the School.

Feedback: Verbal feedback immediately following the seminar presentation is provided by the course coordinator and the supervisor; formal written feedback as per the above marking criteria is provided to the student within 1 week of the presentation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"19f4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"91f4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961966","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"edf4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961968","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"85f4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961940","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Literature Survey Submission","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"","description":"

Students are required to submit a polished copy of their completed Literature Survey and coversheet signed by their supervisor that it is complete and of a satisfactory standard. Students are to receive formative feedback from their supervisor prior to submission and submit with the accompanying feedback form.

Feedback: The Introduction and Literature Survey chapters are submitted in Term 1 and marked by the supervisor to provide formative assessment and feedback to the student.  The completed thesis is graded by the student's supervisor and another independent academic from the School following submission at the end of Term 3.  The name of the independent grading academic is not given to the student.  The average of the above marks is reported to the student in writing (via Moodle) following the release of results at the end of Term 3.  All feedback and discussion concerning the marked work is provided by the student's supervisor.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"19f4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"2df4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a96196b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"55f4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961963","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"91f4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961966","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"edf4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961968","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c5f4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961949","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project management plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"5","description":"

Students are required to submit a project management plan for the Honours Project covering the following elements:  executive summary describing the project to be undertaken and its scope; goals of the project; detailed project planning; resource allocation; budgeting and cost estimation; scheduling; monitoring and project control; project auditing; and project termination.

Feedback: The assignment is marked by the course coordinator using a standardised rubric.  Written feedback is given by the course coordinator and verbal feedback is given by the student's supervisor. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"2df4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a96196b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"55f4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961963","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"91f4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961966","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"cdf4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961944","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Thesis Progress Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"","description":"

Students are required to submit a Thesis Progress Report signed by student and supervisor outlining progress, delays against the project plan and anticipated tasks remaining.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"55f4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961963","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"91f4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a961966","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"cdf4aae7dbf99850eb6b147a3a96194d","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/MATS5003.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description: An experimental or technical investigation or design related to some aspects of materials engineering in the specific discipline (ceramic engineering, metallurgical engineering or materials engineering). This is a 6 UOC supplementary course for students who have taken or are taking both MATS5001 and MATS5002 and wish to undertake an 18 UOC total thesis project.Note: for students who have not undertaken MATS5001 and MATS5002 please be aware that these courses may be taken as co-requisites with MATS5003.
contentlets.title: Advanced Thesis

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MATS6001","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATS6001 - Fundamentals of Materials Processing","description":"

This first section of this course includes an introduction to processing of inorganic materials, semiconductor processing, single crystal growth of Si, GaAs, carbon-based material, thin film processing (physical and chemical vapour deposition), sputtering and pulse laser deposition method advanced nanostructures such as nanoparticles, nanowires, nanotubes, wet chemical methods, electro-less and electrochemical methods. In addition, this course will cover sustainable materials processing- waste plastic, electronics waste processing and sustainable iron and Steel making.


Course material covered in the second section includes secondary metals processing such as fixed and continuous casting processes including sand-box casting, investment casting, die-casting, slab and twin-roll strip-casting; metal billet and sheet rolling; tube and bar extrusion; forging techniques; Powder consolidation techniques including hot isostatic pressing and spark plasma sintering; Soldering, Brazing and Welding, Subtractive manufacturing including multi-axis milling, machining, grinding and spark erosion; Additive manufacturing including typical 3D printing techniques such as extrusion melting, selective laser melting/sintering, e-beam melting and droplet ejection.

Course material covered in the second section includes secondary metals processing such as fixed and continuous casting processes including sand-box casting, investment casting, die-casting, slab and twin-roll strip-casting; metal billet and sheet rolling; tube and bar extrusion; forging techniques; Powder consolidation techniques including hot isostatic pressing and spark plasma sintering; Soldering, Brazing and Welding, Subtractive manufacturing including multi-axis milling, machining, grinding and spark erosion; Additive manufacturing including typical 3D printing techniques such as extrusion melting, selective laser melting/sintering, e-beam melting and droplet ejection.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MATS6002","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATS6002 - Fundamentals of Materials Design","description":"

This course covers a background on the relationship between materials structure and properties and hence the application of advanced engineering materials; including the elastic moduli, yield strength, tensile strength, hardness and ductility, fast fracture, toughness and fatigue, creep deformation and fracture, oxidation and corrosion, friction, abrasion and wear of materials.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"90d68db3db791c50eb6b147a3a961985","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Report and presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will be required to conduct research on a topic involving materials, properties, design parameters, performance, and/or failure.

Requirements
-A formal document, written to a professional standard
-A formal presentation

Students will be given feedback on the content and quality of their presentation within 2 weeks of the submission of their report and presentation

Feedback: Students will receive their marked exams indicating what questions were answered correctly and incorrectly. Overall comments and worked solutions may be provided to the class.
