","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MATS6003","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATS6003 - Presentation Skills for Materials Technology","description":"

This course covers selected topics in presentation skills including public speaking, presentation techniques, visual aids, resume and cover letter writing skills, interview skills, web design, and the use of the persuasive media. This will provide students will skills that will assist in the development of their professional skills and give them the necessary knowledge and skills to conduct presentations at conferences and to succeed in interviews.  


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1da2747fdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619f9","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Use of electronic media in persuasive communication","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will be assessed on their presentation skills demonstrated through the creation of powerpoint presentations, webpages and/or blogs describing contemporary projects in materials science and engineering. 


Feedback will be given to students within 2 weeks of the assessment being performed.    

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"11a2747fdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619f6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"59a2747fdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619ed","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"95a2747fdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d1a2747fdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619f3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"49a2747fdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619ce","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Literature Search","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will write a short report on a project using library skills learnt as part of the course. 


Feedback will be given to students within 2 weeks of the assessment being performed.  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"95a2747fdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619f0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"81a2747fdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619d3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

Students will give a number of oral presentations and a poster presentation based on their thesis work or another materials related project.


Students will be given feedback on the content and quality of their presentations within 2 weeks of the presentation.

This course covers selected topics in management skills for the materials industry. Students will understand the basic elements of management including project planning, financial tools, strategic analysis and professional ethics.

For the business scenario/problem in the Lean Canvas Business Case you are required to identify the various risks to it and their causes, perform a risk analysis to determine the risk rating (consequence x likelihood) and finally recommend control measures/treatments to reduce the risks to acceptable levels.  Specific details of the assessment task will be provided separately.

Feedback will be given to students within two weeks of the assessment being performed.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2f33bcbfdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6b33bcbfdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"a733bcbfdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619f5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"eb33bcbfdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ef33bcbfdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619ec","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1733bcbfdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619d4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Management Plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

For the business scenario/problem in the Lean Canvas Business Case, you develop a detailed project management plan for its implementation.  Specific details of the assessment task will be provided separately.  Specific details of the assessment task will be provided separately.

 

Feedback will be given to students within two weeks of the assessment being performed.    

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2f33bcbfdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6b33bcbfdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"a733bcbfdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619f5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"eb33bcbfdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ef33bcbfdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619ec","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4b33bcbfdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619c6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Management Research Topic","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

Students are to research a selected management topic (from a list of topics provided by course coordinator) and to prepare a detailed research report outlining the management theory underlying the topic and to evaluate current practices employed by management.  For the latter, students will be expected to contact at least one company to conduct an interview to survey their current practices. Topics and details of the assessment requirements are provided separately. (Individual Work Only)

Students will be given feedback on the content and quality of their presentation within two weeks of submission

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2f33bcbfdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"a733bcbfdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619f5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9333bcbfdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619cb","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Business case assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Part 1- Lean Canvas Development: A selection of business scenarios/problems will be provided (students can also suggest their own for approval by course coordinator).  Each group should choose one scenario and conduct any business analyses you consider appropriate to identify the viability of such an operation.  This will include statement of the problem, potential solutions, unique value proposition, target customers/markets, cost structure etc.  You should make and justify a recommendation (either to proceed or not proceed).  Your analyses should draw conclusions of the viability of the operation in the context of the Australian market.  Specific details of the assessment task will be provided separately.

 Part 2 Complete Case and Pitch: For the lean canvas developed in Business Case – Pt 1, students will develop this into a coherent written business case and prepare a group video to present their work.  The Business Case Assignment and Pitch is intended to utilise any/all aspects of the course material and serves to integrate understanding of the course content.  Specific details of the assessment task will be provided separately.

(Groups of 5 max.)

Feedback will be given to students within two weeks of the assessment being performed.  

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2f33bcbfdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6b33bcbfdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"a733bcbfdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619f5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"eb33bcbfdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ef33bcbfdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619ec","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"db33bcbfdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619cf","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/MATS6004.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Balance theory and practical experience to foster career goals.","url":"http://www.science.unsw.edu.au","name_url":"Faculty of Science","name_no_url":""}],"requisites":[],"unit_offering":[],"academic_calendar_tooltip":"Consists of three standard terms, each with ten weeks teaching, and an optional five week summer term.  Some programs in Medicine, AGSM, and UNSW Global have different term dates.  See the university website for details.","academic_item_type":"Course","no_enrolment":"false","offering_detail":{"key":"ugrd","fees":{},"offering_terms":"","fees_table":"","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"MATS6006","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATS6006 - Recycling of Materials","description":"

You will learn about the growing generation of materials waste streams arising from rapid urbanisation and growing populations, how to categorise them and evaluate their environmental impacts if not treated properly. You will also learn about suitable techniques to manage different categories of materials waste and minimise their environmental impact. You will explore various recycling approaches using a range of different methods including mechanical, electrical, chemical and thermal treatment of materials. This course places a heightened focus on authentic learning experience through multiple visits to labs and state-of-art waste processing equipment.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a6ea6173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961959","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Waste categorisation essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will be asked to select one type of materials waste of their interest and conduct research to learn about the material, its environmental impact and implications for effective management of this category of material at different levels.

Written feedback will be given on the returned assignment 2 weeks after submission is finalised.  General class feedback will be given on the following lecture.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5eea6173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961952","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"96ea6173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96194a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"9aea6173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961955","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d2ea6173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96194d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0eea6173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961937","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Site Visit Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will visit different labs and observe the operation of different state-of-art equipment which are used for waste processing such as SelFrag, furnaces, TGA-FTIR-GCMS, high temperature laser scanning confocal microscope, potentiostat and etc. In the report, students will be required to compare and contrast the techniques used at the different sites and evaluate the way they lessen the environmental impacts of the wastes in relation to a broader range of techniques used world-wide. Based on the evaluation, they will be required to make recommendations for improvement and implications for the use of the techniques world-wide, national and local contexts.

Feedback: Written feedback will be given on the returned assignment 2 weeks after submission is finalised.  General class feedback will be given on the following lecture.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"12ea6173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5eea6173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961952","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"9aea6173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961955","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"86ea6173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96193c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Recycling evaluation report","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Students will be asked to select one type of materials waste from a given list. They will be required to: i. categorise the materials waste, ii. discuss the environmental impacts of this material if it ends up in landfill or liberates to the atmosphere as toxic emission, iii. identify and justify a suitable approach and methods to recycle the material, iv. apply the life cycle assessment framework to evaluate the environmental impacts of using the method(s) compared to non-treated disposal of the material waste, and v. propose strategies to policy makers to introduce and/or reinforce the implementation of the recycling methods in a national or an Australian state or a local context of their choice.

Written feedback will be given on the returned assignment 2 weeks after submission is finalised.

You will also learn about suitable techniques to manage different categories of materials waste and minimise their environmental impact. You will explore various recycling approaches using a range of different methods including mechanical, electrical, chemical and thermal treatment of materials. This course places a heightened focus on authentic learning experience through multiple visits to labs and state-of-art waste processing equipment.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MATS6006","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATS6006 - Recycling of Materials","description":"

You will learn about the growing generation of materials waste streams arising from rapid urbanisation and growing populations, how to categorise them and evaluate their environmental impacts if not treated properly. You will also learn about suitable techniques to manage different categories of materials waste and minimise their environmental impact. You will explore various recycling approaches using a range of different methods including mechanical, electrical, chemical and thermal treatment of materials. This course places a heightened focus on authentic learning experience through multiple visits to labs and state-of-art waste processing equipment.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a6ea6173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961959","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Waste categorisation essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will be asked to select one type of materials waste of their interest and conduct research to learn about the material, its environmental impact and implications for effective management of this category of material at different levels.

Written feedback will be given on the returned assignment 2 weeks after submission is finalised.  General class feedback will be given on the following lecture.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5eea6173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961952","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"96ea6173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96194a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"9aea6173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961955","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d2ea6173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96194d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0eea6173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961937","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Site Visit Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will visit different labs and observe the operation of different state-of-art equipment which are used for waste processing such as SelFrag, furnaces, TGA-FTIR-GCMS, high temperature laser scanning confocal microscope, potentiostat and etc. In the report, students will be required to compare and contrast the techniques used at the different sites and evaluate the way they lessen the environmental impacts of the wastes in relation to a broader range of techniques used world-wide. Based on the evaluation, they will be required to make recommendations for improvement and implications for the use of the techniques world-wide, national and local contexts.

Feedback: Written feedback will be given on the returned assignment 2 weeks after submission is finalised.  General class feedback will be given on the following lecture.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"12ea6173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5eea6173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961952","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"9aea6173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961955","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"86ea6173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96193c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Recycling evaluation report","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Students will be asked to select one type of materials waste from a given list. They will be required to: i. categorise the materials waste, ii. discuss the environmental impacts of this material if it ends up in landfill or liberates to the atmosphere as toxic emission, iii. identify and justify a suitable approach and methods to recycle the material, iv. apply the life cycle assessment framework to evaluate the environmental impacts of using the method(s) compared to non-treated disposal of the material waste, and v. propose strategies to policy makers to introduce and/or reinforce the implementation of the recycling methods in a national or an Australian state or a local context of their choice.

Written feedback will be given on the returned assignment 2 weeks after submission is finalised.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"12ea6173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5eea6173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961952","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"96ea6173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96194a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"9aea6173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961955","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d2ea6173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96194d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ceea6173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961940","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/MATS6006.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MATS6007","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATS6007 - Sustainable Materials Engineering","description":"

We live in a material world. The last decade's unprecedented worldwide growth in materials production and consumption has challenged our planet and left considerable impacts on environment. Mitigating the impact of materials utilisation and minimising our environmental footprint is urgent. This urgency requires us to explore and apply effective strategies, both legal and technical, for promoting materials sustainability. You will learn about all these themes and explore various approaches towards creating a sustainable system from the viewpoint of Materials Science and Engineering.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"6a60fdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619da","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Sustainable materials essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will be asked to find one real-world example related to one of the five material-focused transformative strategies and assess how the strategy can contribute to creating a sustainable system. Based on their assessment, students will propose recommendations for improvement and draw implications for efforts to create a sustainable system more broadly.

Feedback: Written feedback will be given on the returned assignment 2 weeks after submission is finalised.  General class feedback will be given on the following lecture.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6e60fdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d260fdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"de60fdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0a60fdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619a7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Students will undertake a 2 hr written exam covering the content taught within the whole course, held during the final exam period. Students will be asked to apply the concepts learnt in the course to real-world situations and justify their materials selection and assess their implications on the environment, through a mix of short and long answer questions. 

Feedback: Students will be given their final mark with the release of marks by UNSW 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2260fdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6e60fdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d260fdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"de60fdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1a60fdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619b8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Materials Impact on the Enivroment","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will be asked to identify a material type and do research to evaluate the environmental impact of that material from extraction to disposal and draw implications for how to minimise these environmental impacts.

Feedback: Written feedback will be given on the returned assignment 2 weeks after submission is finalised.  General class feedback will be given on the following lecture.

Balance theory and practical experience to foster career goals.","url":"http://www.science.unsw.edu.au","name_url":"Faculty of Science","name_no_url":""}],"requisites":[],"unit_offering":[],"academic_calendar_tooltip":"Consists of three standard terms, each with ten weeks teaching, and an optional five week summer term.  Some programs in Medicine, AGSM, and UNSW Global have different term dates.  See the university website for details.","academic_item_type":"Course","no_enrolment":"false","offering_detail":{"key":"ugrd","fees":{},"offering_terms":"","fees_table":"","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"MATS6007","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATS6007 - Sustainable Materials Engineering","description":"

We live in a material world. The last decade's unprecedented worldwide growth in materials production and consumption has challenged our planet and left considerable impacts on environment. Mitigating the impact of materials utilisation and minimising our environmental footprint is urgent. This urgency requires us to explore and apply effective strategies, both legal and technical, for promoting materials sustainability. You will learn about all these themes and explore various approaches towards creating a sustainable system from the viewpoint of Materials Science and Engineering.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"6a60fdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619da","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Sustainable materials essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will be asked to find one real-world example related to one of the five material-focused transformative strategies and assess how the strategy can contribute to creating a sustainable system. Based on their assessment, students will propose recommendations for improvement and draw implications for efforts to create a sustainable system more broadly.

Feedback: Written feedback will be given on the returned assignment 2 weeks after submission is finalised.  General class feedback will be given on the following lecture.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6e60fdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d260fdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"de60fdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0a60fdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619a7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Students will undertake a 2 hr written exam covering the content taught within the whole course, held during the final exam period. Students will be asked to apply the concepts learnt in the course to real-world situations and justify their materials selection and assess their implications on the environment, through a mix of short and long answer questions. 

Feedback: Students will be given their final mark with the release of marks by UNSW 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2260fdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6e60fdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d260fdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"de60fdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1a60fdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619b8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Materials Impact on the Enivroment","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will be asked to identify a material type and do research to evaluate the environmental impact of that material from extraction to disposal and draw implications for how to minimise these environmental impacts.

Feedback: Written feedback will be given on the returned assignment 2 weeks after submission is finalised.  General class feedback will be given on the following lecture.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6e60fdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"de60fdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ce60fdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619a2","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/MATS6007.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MATS6008","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATS6008 - Advanced Functional Materials","description":"

Students will investigate the design, composition, processing methods, structure, physical properties and applications of a range of advanced functional materials. You will learn a number of techniques associated with the fabrication and physical property testing of functional materials. You will explore how the properties of these materials can be tuned through careful control over material chemistry or the fabrication method chosen for their production. You will learn to apply what you have learned to design new functional materials suitable to specific applications from the viewpoint of Materials Science and Engineering.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"7938d533db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961962","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory workbook","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

There will be a number of lab sessions where students will investigate the fabrication of 2D materials using both bottom-up and top-down methods. They will be provided with material samples, use the microscopy to characterise the samples’ structure and conduct tests on the physical properties of the materials. For assessment, students will be required to keep a lab workbook of the microscopic investigation of the samples’ structure and test results. They will then be required to draw on the results to discuss the relationship between processing route, structure and properties of the sample materials and  critique how changes in processing route affect behaviour of the material to suit specific applications.

\n

Written feedback will be given on the returned lab report 2 weeks after submission is finalised.  General class feedback will be given in the following lecture.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"7d38d533db3d1c50eb6b147a3a96195e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b538d533db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961956","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f138d533db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961959","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2938d533db3d1c50eb6b147a3a96192f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"45","description":"

Students will be asked to undertake a 2 hr written exam covering the content taught within the whole course. To be held during the final exam period. Students will be asked to apply the concepts learnt in the course to real-world situations.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3138d533db3d1c50eb6b147a3a96195c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"7d38d533db3d1c50eb6b147a3a96195e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b538d533db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961956","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f138d533db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961959","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2938d533db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961940","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Advanced Functional Materials Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will be asked to select a class or a subclass of functional material and justify their choice. They will then be required to do research to examine the relationship between composition, processing, structure, physical properties and potential applications of the selected class/subclass of functional material. They will also be required to evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of the material, as well as implications for the potential applications.

\n

Written feedback will be given on the returned assignment 2 weeks after submission is finalised.  General class feedback will be given in the following lecture.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"7d38d533db3d1c50eb6b147a3a96195e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b538d533db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961956","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f138d533db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961959","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ed38d533db3d1c50eb6b147a3a96192a","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/MATS6008.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MATS6009","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATS6009 - Advanced Alloys","description":"

Students will investigate the design, composition, processing methods, structure, physical and mechanical properties and applications of a range of advanced alloys. They will learn about the first principles, models and thermodynamic databases that underpin alloy design and apply them to the development of alloys suitable to specific applications. They will also examine the relationships between composition, processing variables, structure, mechanical and physical properties and applications of these cutting-edge materials from the viewpoint of Materials Science and Engineering.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c9389533db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b2","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tutorial workbook","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

This assessment task aims to develop the students’ capacity in materials modelling as well as their understanding of the relationships between composition and structure. Students will be required to complete relevant activities in the workbook during their weekly tutorials. Weeks 1-4 activities will focus on structural and performance criteria and how to select suitable software, techniques and/or technologies to test materials according to these criteria. Weeks 5-7 activities will require students to work on a problem, derive the structural and/or performance criteria for the end product that has potential to solve the problem, and use computer models and databases to generate compositions that meet their specified structural and/or performance criteria.

\n

Written feedback will be given on the returned assignment 2 weeks after submission is finalised.  General class feedback will be given in the following lecture.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"09389533db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"81389533db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ac","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"cd389533db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"38389533db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961998","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Students will be asked to undertake a 2 hr written exam covering the content taught within the whole course, held during the final exam period. Students will be asked to answer a range of long and short answer questions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"09389533db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"45389533db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"81389533db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ac","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"cd389533db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"70389533db3d1c50eb6b147a3a96199d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Advanced Alloy Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Students will be asked to select a class or a subclass of alloy and justify their choice. They will then be required to conduct research to examine the relationship between composition, processing route, microstructure, properties of the selected alloy and its applications.

\n

Written feedback will be given on the returned assignment 2 weeks after submission is finalised.  General class feedback will be given in the following lecture.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MATS6101","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATS6101 - Thermodynamics and Phase Equilibria","description":"
  • Fundamentals of thermodynamics (thermodynamics basics; heat, work, and internal energy; heat capacity; enthalpy, entropy, and free energy; three laws of thermodynamics; redox processes).
  • Equilibrium and gas-solid phase transitions (chemical equilibrium, first- and second-order phase transitions, fugacity and activity, gas-solid equilibria, Ellingham diagrams).
  • Solution thermodynamics and phase diagram construction (Gibbs-Duhem equation. Raoult's and Henry's laws. Solutions and activity and phase diagram construction).
  • Interpretation and applications of binary and ternary phase diagrams (unary systems, binary systems, ternary effects on microstructures, phase calculations, drawing isothermal and vertical sections of real ternary systems).

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"88064d33db791c50eb6b147a3a961931","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will be required to complete two problem-based assignments in the areas of phase diagrams.
Students will be given the first problem set on Monday Week 6 and the second problem on Monday week 8.

Feedback will be given two weeks after submission of the assignment and take the form of the mark for the assignment, overall comments on how the class performed, any common areas that were not answered correctly. Additionally, personal feedback and how each student performed may be given.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"37f54d33db791c50eb6b147a3a961928","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"73f54d33db791c50eb6b147a3a96192b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"8c064d33db791c50eb6b147a3a96192d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"23f54d33db791c50eb6b147a3a96190b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

The examination will be 2 h in duration. The only area covered will be the interpretation and applications of applications of unary, binary and ternary phase diagrams.

 

Feedback: Students will receive their final mark.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"33f54d33db791c50eb6b147a3a961919","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"37f54d33db791c50eb6b147a3a961928","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"73f54d33db791c50eb6b147a3a96192b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"8c064d33db791c50eb6b147a3a96192d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7bf54d33db791c50eb6b147a3a96190f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Students will be required to complete a problem-based assignment in the areas of equilibrium and gas-solid phase transitions.

Assignment 1 will be posted on Moodle in Week 5
Submissions after the deadline will not be assessed. 

Feedback will be given two weeks after submission of the assignment and take the form of the mark for the assignment, overall comments on how the class performed, any common areas that were not answered correctly. Additionally, personal feedback and how each student performed may be given.

contentlets.keywords: materials science and engineering,material structure,thermodynamics,phase equilibria,phase diagrams
contentlets.description:
• Fundamentals of thermodynamics (thermodynamics basics; heat, work, and internal energy; heat capacity; enthalpy, entropy, and free energy; three laws of thermodynamics; redox processes).
  • Equilibrium and gas-solid phase transitions (chemical equilibrium, first- and second-order phase transitions, fugacity and activity, gas-solid equilibria, Ellingham diagrams).
  • Solution thermodynamics and phase diagram construction (Gibbs-Duhem equation. Raoult's and Henry's laws. Solutions and activity and phase diagram construction).
  • Interpretation and applications of binary and ternary phase diagrams (unary systems, binary systems, ternary effects on microstructures, phase calculations, drawing isothermal and vertical sections of real ternary systems).
contentlets.title: Thermodynamics and Phase Equilibria

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MATS6102","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATS6102 - Kinetics and Phase Transformations","description":"

This course covers a background on the relationship between kinetics, diffusion, phase transformations and the prediction of materials microstructure. Students will understand how to predict materials structure based on the principles of phase transformations and apply this knowledge to commercial alloys.


Kinetics - Reaction rate definition, the rate law, rate constant and order. Experimental determination of the rate law: the method of initial rates, methods using integrated rate equations for 1st order and 2nd order reactions; rate constants, half-life. Effect of temperature on reaction rates: the Arrhenius equation, activation energy and frequency factor. Elementary reactions, mechanism, rate-determining step; in relation to the rate law.  Complex reactions: opposing, consecutive and parallel reactions; catalysis and catalysts; enzyme catalysis, Michaelis-Menten mechanisms, molecular reaction kinetics and collision theory.


Diffusion Fundamentals - Introduction to diffusion in gasses, liquids, membrane transport, facilitated diffusion, osmosis, diffusion in solids and thin films, Fick’s first and second laws and other factors affecting diffusion. 


Diffusion case studies – We will see how the fundamentals of diffusion learnt in weeks 1-5 can be applied to solve real problems encountered for various materials processing phenomena. Based on such case studies an appreciation of the complexities of applying diffusion laws will be learnt. Finally, students will analyse a different set of topics of how the principles of Diffusion and Kinetics learnt in weeks 1-5 can be applied for their research paper.

Feedback will be given to students within 2 weeks of the assessment being performed.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MATS6104","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATS6104 - Physical Properties of Materials","description":"

The course will give an overview of modern research topics in material physics with the purpose of encouraging students to engage in the latest research. The focus will be on introducing a simple physical model with just enough mathematical formalism to explain the physics in complex materials. In the first two parts of the course, the fundamentals of modern electronic structure theory and electrical conductions in solids will be introduced. In the third part of the course, some fundamental excitation processes will be discussed, including phonons and optical properties of materials. Non-covalent interactions, which plays an important role in determining the stabilities of low-dimensional and molecular materials, will be discussed, particularly their deep root to the electronic structures of materials. Finally, students will have a chance to gain knowledge on the latest researches in understanding structure-property relationships in complex materials with computation modellings using techniques such as machine-learnings. Stronger focus geared towards research at postgraduate level are incorporated into the second half of the course, and students will be giving group presentations to discuss specific topics on the latest research in physical properties of materials.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"b378c1f7db791c50eb6b147a3a96194b","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignments","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

You will be required to undertake calculations involving the application of modern electron theory to topics covered throughout the course including
-The wave nature of electrons
-Electrical conduction in metals, semiconductors and insulators

Feedback will be given two weeks after submission of the assignment and take the form of the marked assignment, comments on how the class performed, and any common areas that were not answered correctly. Additionally, personal feedback and how each student performed may be given. A solution sheet for each assignment, showing the worked answers and relevant comments, will be uploaded onto Moodle two weeks after their submission.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2f78c1f7db791c50eb6b147a3a961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6b78c1f7db791c50eb6b147a3a961903","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b778c1f7db791c50eb6b147a3a961906","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"b778c1f7db791c50eb6b147a3a961947","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"577881f7db791c50eb6b147a3a9619c4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-term Examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

The aim of this exam is to assess students’ skills in solving problems concerning introductory aspects of electron theory and its application to materials science and engineering (Parts I & II).  It will consist of a combination of multiple choice and essay-style questions involving some calculations. Any derivations will assume knowledge of the material rather than memorizing equations with relevant background equations provided.

As the mid-term exam is the formal exam for Part 1 of the course, with the content not examinable in Part 2, students will receive their final mark.

Students are expected to summarize their understanding the topics presented in week 10 in 1 short reports

Feedback will be given two weeks after submission of the assignment and take the form of the marked assignment, comments on how the class performed, and any common areas that were not answered correctly. Additionally, personal feedback and how each student performed may be given. A solution sheet for each assignment, showing the worked answers and relevant comments, will be uploaded onto Moodle two weeks after their submission.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MATS6105","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATS6105 - Chemical Properties of Materials","description":"

This course covers the chemical properties of materials, especially corrosion and oxidation. Focus is placed on strategies to prevent the corrosion and oxidation of engineering materials. Students will understand the practical consequences of corrosion and oxidation and the role of materials selection and design in reducing these phenomena.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"9ea2b47fdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619a2","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-term Examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

The in-class exam will cover the topics taught in weeks 1-5.

Feedback: Students will receive their marked exams indicating what questions were answered correctly and incorrectly. Overall comments and worked solutions may be provided to the class.

Presentation: 7-10 minute oral presentation given to the class based on the group’s project

Lab 1 can be performed by each student on their own.
Lab 2 the students will be divided into groups of 5 ~ 6, depending on the number of students in the class. Details of the labs will be provided in a later stage.

Feedback: Students will receive their mark and individualised feedback on the areas they excelled at and which areas of the reports that were not answered correctly. Feedback will be provided through Moodle, two weeks after submission.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8aa2b47fdb751c50eb6b147a3a961980","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c6a2b47fdb751c50eb6b147a3a961983","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b5a2b47fdb751c50eb6b147a3a961963","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

Four short ongoing assignments on the following topics:
1: Corrosion (Part 1=5%, Part 2=5%)
2: Surface treatment (10%)
3: Electrochemistry of materials (10%)

Feedback will be given two weeks after submission of the assignment and take the form of the mark for the assignment, overall comments on how the class performed, any common areas that were not answered correctly. Additionally, personal feedback and how each student performed may be given.

contentlets.description: This course covers the chemical properties of materials, especially corrosion and oxidation. Focus is placed on strategies to prevent the corrosion and oxidation of engineering materials. Students will understand the practical consequences of corrosion and oxidation and the role of materials selection and design in reducing these phenomena.
contentlets.title: Chemical Properties of Materials

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MATS6106","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATS6106 - Mechanical Properties of Materials","description":"

Crystallography revision. Theoretical strength; slip; twinning; deformation of single and polycrystals; dislocation multiplication; cross slip; climb; dislocation interactions. Strain-strain curves of different metal crystals. Theories of the yield point and flow stress. Temperature dependence of flow stress, high-temperature deformation and creep. Advanced theories on strengthening mechanisms of metals.  Superalloys and composite materials to be taught illustrating some of the principles involved.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MATS6107","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATS6107 - Thermal Properties of Ceramics","description":"

This course covers the thermal properties of materials, especially the temperature dependent applications of ceramic materials. Emphasis is placed on enhancing the thermal stability as well thermally induced functional responses of these materials.  Processing methods used to manufacture these materials will also be studied. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"de3de1f7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961966","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-term Examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Midterm exam feedback will be given in 2 weeks via Moodle.

 

Topics: Electrical, electromechanical, magnetic and optoelectronic properties, and materials

Duration: 2 hours

Feedback: Students will receive their marked exams indicating what questions were answered correctly and incorrectly. Overall comments and worked solutions may be provided to the class.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4a3de1f7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96195d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"863de1f7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d23de1f7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961963","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"313de1f7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96194b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Topics: Thermal properties (heat capacity, thermal conductivity, thermal expansion) and Electrothermal properties (pyroelectric, electrocaloric, thermoelectric)

Duration: 2 hours

Feedback: Students will receive their final mark.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4a3de1f7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96195d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"863de1f7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d23de1f7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961963","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4a3de1f7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96194f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"In class short quiz (each worth 5%)","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Short quizzes based on the case studies covered in class.  Case studies are covered in the second lecture of the week from weeks 6 to 10. There will be 4 quizzes - each week's content will be quizzed on the week. These will be held in the second half of the second lecture of the week.  The short quiz will have a combination of multiple choice questions, short answers, graphical analysis and providing commentary on published case studies.

The quiz answers will discussed in class at the completion of the quiz. Feedback on students performance will be provided within 1 week so that they can improve their score for the next quiz.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4a3de1f7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96195d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"863de1f7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d23de1f7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961963","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"823de1f7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961954","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

An assignment which has 5 short answer questions based on content covered in Weeks 1-5. this assignment is due in Week 5.

Feedback will be given two weeks after submission of the assignment and take the form of the mark for the assignment, overall comments on how the class performed, any common areas that were not answered correctly. Additionally, personal feedback and how each student performed may be given.

This was done based on feedback from students who preferred a traditional assignment to learn the contents better.

This course covers the fabrication, structure, properties and applications of composite and functional materials. Students will gain an understanding of the relationship between materials design, fabrication and behaviour of these materials.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1ea6c5b3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619cd","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Literature review","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Students will be required to conduct research (literature review) on following topics; (1) Electronic devices such as; non-volatile memories, transistors etc. (2) Devices involved Magnetic fields, magnetic moments, or current induced magneto-electronic effects.

A formal document, written to a professional standard (2500-3000 words)

Feedback: Feedback will be given two weeks after submission of the assignment and take the form of the mark for the assignment, overall comments on how the class performed, any common areas that were not answered correctly. Additionally, personal feedback and how each student performed may be given.

This examination will be the final examination for the topics learnt in Weeks 1-5

Feedback: Students will receive their marks. Overall comments and worked solutions may be provided to the class.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"12a6c5b3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"92a6c5b3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d2a6c5b3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619c7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"dea6c5b3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619b7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4aa6c5b3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619a2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Each group of students will be required to do a 10-minute presentation on their selected topics from the core content taught from weeks 5-10. No two groups can take the same topic; however, topics will need to be discussed with the tutor between weeks 5-10. The marking will be dependent on the audience engagement and 10 minutes Q&A session after the presentation.

Feedback: Feedback will be given two weeks after submission of the assignment and take the form of the mark for the assignment, overall comments on how the class performed, any common areas that were not answered correctly. Additionally, personal feedback and how each student performed may be given.

 

 

 

 

Mid-session test will include a range of questions include essay, numerical problems and short answer questions.This will constitute 30% of the overall assessment for this course. 

 

 

 

 

 

Feedback will a to students within 2 weeks of the assessment being performed.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MATS6109","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATS6109 - Polymer Materials Science","description":"

1st Component: Fundamentals of Polymer Science and Engineering


  • Polymer Chemistry and Synthesis: raw materials and synthesis of polymers; monomers, homopolymers, copolymers; basic organic chemistry and applied polymer chemistry; free radical polymerization, kinetics and mechanism; ionic and condensation polymerization, kinetics and mechanism.
  • Polymer Physics and Characterisation: chain dimensions; polymer thermodynamics; polymer solution behaviour; characterisation techniques in solution and solid state using spectroscopy, chromatography and colligative properties.

2nd Component: Case Studies of Polymer Design and Failure


  • Mechanical Properties: viscoelasticity and elastic deformation; structure-property relationship Case Studies: polymer properties; failure modes and causes of degradation; analytical techniques for characterising the failing components; examples of polymeric devices that have failed across a broad range of applications such as medical and industrial.
  • Design Project: field of application; material selection (synthetic route); polymer structure and property; processing technique; characterisation tools; the relation between structure and application;

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATS6110 - Computational Materials Science","description":"

This course covers the principles and application of solving materials science problems through computational approaches. Modelling packages such as ANSYS will be used to solve problems in areas of fluid dynamics and the structural properties of advanced materials.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"fc064d33db791c50eb6b147a3a9619ac","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-term Examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Theory and practical: It will assess understanding of the CFD theory and ability to solve materials problems encountered in design using the FLUENT CFD package; both on the ANSYS Workbench platform.

Students will receive their marked exams indicating what questions were answered correctly and incorrectly. Overall comments and worked solutions may be provided to the class.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2c064d33db791c50eb6b147a3a9619a0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1c064d33db791c50eb6b147a3a961970","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Literature Review Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

You will be asked to undertake a review of recently published literature and write a post on an online forum about 2 papers. You will also peer review posts from other students.

: Feedback will be given two weeks after submission of the assignment and take the form of the mark for the assignment, overall comments on how the class performed, any common areas that were not answered correctly. Additionally, personal feedback and how each student performed may be given.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2c064d33db791c50eb6b147a3a9619a0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b4064d33db791c50eb6b147a3a9619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f0064d33db791c50eb6b147a3a9619a9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2c064d33db791c50eb6b147a3a961992","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Computational Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"25","description":"

You will undertake a set of numerical problems and practical exercises using commercial software to apply molecular mechanics calculations and molecular dynamics simulations to problems in materials science.

Feedback will be given two weeks after submission of the assignment and take the form of the mark for the assignment, overall comments on how the class performed, any common areas that were not answered correctly. Additionally, personal feedback and how each student recently may be given.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2c064d33db791c50eb6b147a3a9619a0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"78064d33db791c50eb6b147a3a9619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b4064d33db791c50eb6b147a3a9619a6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"64064d33db791c50eb6b147a3a961997","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment1","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

You are required to solve a partial differential equation using finite difference and finite volume methods. You will also need to develop a CFD model using Pro/E and FLUENT software packages on the ANSYS Workbench platform to solve a typical fluid and heat flow problem in material processing.

You are required to attend the lab practices and submit the results at the end of the practices.

Feedback will be given two weeks after submission of the assignment and take the form of the mark for the assignment, overall comments on how the class performed, any common areas that were not answered correctly. Additionally, personal feedback and how each student performed may be given

contentlets.keywords: materials science and engineering,finite elemental modelling,computational fluid dynamics
contentlets.description: This course covers the principles and application of solving materials science problems through computational approaches. Modelling packages such as ANSYS will be used to solve problems in areas of fluid dynamics and the structural properties of advanced materials.
contentlets.title: Computational Materials Science

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MATS6111","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATS6111 - Processes in Materials Engineering","description":"

Solidification, welding (emphasis on effect of welding on microstructure, HAZ’s etc), fundamentals of metal working (including hot working, Zener-Hollomon parameter, dynamic recovery and recrystallization and cold working including slip-line field theory, slab and upper bound analyses, formability, residual stresses), recrystallisation phenomena.


This course shall also focus on several advanced topics including: Specialty alloys such as; shape memory alloys, TWIP and TRIP steels, ultra-lightweight alloys, amorphous alloys, high entropy alloys and the associated processing technologies or fundamental mechanisms surrounding them. It shall also cover severe plastic deformation techniques and superplastic forming processes of metals.

contentlets.description:
Solidification, welding (emphasis on effect of welding on microstructure, HAZ’s etc), fundamentals of metal working (including hot working, Zener-Hollomon parameter, dynamic recovery and recrystallization and cold working including slip-line field theory, slab and upper bound analyses, formability, residual stresses), recrystallisation phenomena.

This course shall also focus on several advanced topics including: Specialty alloys such as; shape memory alloys, TWIP and TRIP steels, ultra-lightweight alloys, amorphous alloys, high entropy alloys and the associated processing technologies or fundamental mechanisms surrounding them. It shall also cover severe plastic deformation techniques and superplastic forming processes of metals.
contentlets.title: Processes in Materials Engineering

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MATS6112","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATS6112 - Characterisation of Materials","description":"

This course covers a range of methods in the analysis of materials including diffraction, microscopy and spectroscopy methods. Emphasis is placed on the applicability of each technique to appropriate analysis and the limitations of each method.


The first half of the course (Weeks 1-6) will provide a fundamental understanding of crystallography, diffraction, and electron microscopy (taught with MATS2003).  The second half of the course presents advanced topics in diffraction, microscopy, and spectroscopy.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"91d6cdb3db791c50eb6b147a3a961909","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tutorial/Assignment work","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"35","description":"

Crystallography assignment: Students will determine basic crystallographic relationships and perform crystal structure calculations.
X-ray diffraction: The principle of operation of a powder X-ray diffractometer will be demonstrated to students by means of a video.  Students will determine crystallographic structure factors and diffraction intensities of a selected material from first principles and will use them to compare with measured XRD patterns and to determine the lattice parameters and density of the material.  Identification of phases in a mixed-phase sample will also be done.
Electron Microscopy tutorial: Students use an online interactive SEM simulator to learn the basic operation of an SEM and to determine how image appearance is affected by SEM operating conditions.
Electron Microscopy assignment: Students will interpret topographical and compositional SEM images and data.

Feedback will be given two weeks after submission of the assignment and take the form of the mark for the assignment, overall comments on how the class performed, any common areas that were not answered correctly. Additionally, personal feedback and how each student performed may be given.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"09d68db3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"45d68db3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619f3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"38d68db3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619c0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

The mid-session quiz will provide formative assessment of the fundamentals of Crystallography and X-ray Diffraction as covered by formal lectures, nominated reading material (from course handouts), and assignments.  It will consist of a combination of short-answer style questions and calculations.  Any derivations will assume knowledge of the material with relevant background equations provided (except Bragg’s Law), rather than resorting equations to memory.  The exam will assess both underlying principles of the X-ray Diffraction characterisation technique as well as its application to the practical characterisation of real materials.

Feedback: Students will receive their marked exams indicating what questions were answered correctly and incorrectly. Overall comments and worked solutions may be provided to the class.

 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"09d68db3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"45d68db3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619f3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"81d68db3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619f6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"95d6cdb3db791c50eb6b147a3a961905","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"38d68db3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619e2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

The final exam will provide a summative assessment of the topics of Diffraction, Electron Microscopy, and Spectroscopy as covered by formal lectures nominated reading material (from course handouts), assignments, and laboratories.  It will consist of a combination of short-answer style answers and calculations.  Any derivations will assume knowledge of the material with relevant background equations provided, rather than resorting equations to memory.  The exam will assess both underlying principles of the materials characterisation techniques as well as their application to the practical characterisation of real materials.

Feedback: Students will receive their final mark.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"09d68db3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"45d68db3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619f3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"81d68db3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619f6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"95d6cdb3db791c50eb6b147a3a961905","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"70d68db3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619e7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory Demonstration / Case Studies","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Lab. 1   Diffraction / Atomic Force Microscopy Techniques: The principle of operation of selected X-ray diffractometers and Atomic force microscopes will be demonstrated to students in small groups.  Students will apply crystallographic principles to the interpretation of the resultant XRD data.  (2 hours)

Lab. 2   Electron Microscopy Techniques: Students will work in small groups to employ SEM operating principles learnt in the SEM online tutorial to an actual SEM instrument and will be shown advanced imaging techniques.  Students will report and interpret resultant data.  (2 hours) 

Feedback: Students will receive their mark and individualised feedback on the areas they excelled at and which areas of the reports that were not answered correctly. Feedback will be provided through Moodle, two weeks after submission.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"09d68db3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"45d68db3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619f3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"95d6cdb3db791c50eb6b147a3a961905","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"fcd68db3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619dd","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/MATS6112.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
