","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MATS6113","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"12 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATS6113 - Research Project","description":"

This course is designed for students undertaking a Masters by Coursework program in Materials Science and Engineering. It will be based on the performance of an original research project. Students will need to demonstrate competency in the design and execution of a research investigation.


A self-directed experimental research or design-based project to apply, contextualise, and integrate fundamental scientific/engineering concepts learnt throughout the Materials Science and Engineering undergraduate program.  Students will develop advanced disciplinary knowledge and will apply this to problem solving in the chosen topic area. Students will develop and practice high-level skills in critical thinking, project management, safety consideration and risk management, data collection and analysis, problem solving, and technical communication.


T1 Entry point: Students are required to enrol in MATS6114 in Term 1 and Term 2 and enrol in MATS6113 in Term 3


Note: study arrangements and attendance for this course is made on a case-by-case basis and all enrolments must be processed by the Materials Science & Engineering School Office only. Please contact enquiries@materials.unsw.edu.au.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"4ac2f87fdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619b2","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Literature Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"","description":"

As part of the thesis preparation process the students will submit a draft literature review of their project topic. This would be expected to occur at the end of one session of enrollment. Students would need to be able to demonstrate competency in understanding the research project they are undertaking and be able to clearly identify the research questions that they seek to investigate.


Students would be given feedback on their literature review by their project supervisor within 2 weeks of submission

The thesis is the major piece of work submitted at the end of the 24 UOC research project.   A Materials thesis at this level typically is 100 pages.  It is marked by three nominated academic assessors using a standardised rubric for all theses.

In either case a final grade is withheld until the final course is completed."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATS6114 - Research Project A","description":"

A self-directed experimental research or design-based project to apply, contextualise, and integrate fundamental scientific/engineering concepts learnt throughout the Materials Science and Engineering undergraduate program.  Students will develop advanced disciplinary knowledge and will apply this to problem solving in the chosen topic area. Students will develop and practice high-level skills in critical thinking, project management, safety consideration and risk management, data collection and analysis, problem solving, and technical communication.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"520409fbdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Literature Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"","description":"

As part of the thesis preparation process, the students will submit a draft literature review of their project topic in term 1 of there project. This would be expected to occur at the end of one session of enrolment. Students would need to be able to demonstrate competency in understanding the research project they are undertaking and be able to clearly identify the research questions that they seek to investigate.

Students are required to submit this assessment task throughout the thesis to obtain feedback from their Supervisors and meet the milestones for progression in the course. The section will be given a final grade upon marking of the completed thesis at the end of Term 3.

Students will be given feedback on their literature review by their project supervisor within 2 weeks of submission

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"120409fbdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"560409fbdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619c4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5e0409fbdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9a0409fbdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619a8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d20409fbdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619a0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"060409fbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961981","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Experimental Procedures and Preliminary Results Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"","description":"

As part of the thesis writing process students need to submit a report detailing the work completed in Term 2 of the project at the end of Term 2. The report should contain a draft of the experimental procedures, a draft of any preliminary results. Along with the draft section students need to submit report on the progress they have made so far detailing any issues that have arisen through the project that may affect the final submission of their thesis.

Students are required to submit this assessment task throughout the thesis to obtain feedback from their Supervisors and meet the milestones for progression in the course. The section will be given a final grade upon marking of the completed thesis at the end of Term 3.

Students will be given feedback on their literature review by their project supervisor within 2 weeks of submission

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"120409fbdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"560409fbdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619c4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5e0409fbdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9a0409fbdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619a8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d20409fbdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619a0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0e0409fbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961985","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Thesis","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"90","description":"

The thesis is the major piece of work submitted at the end of the 24 UOC research project.   A Materials thesis at this level typically is 100 pages.  It is marked by three nominated academic assessors using a standardised rubric for all a .

The final thesis is to be submitted in term 3 of the project, the final mark will count towards both terms of MATS6114 and MATS6113.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"120409fbdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"560409fbdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619c4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5e0409fbdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9a0409fbdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619a8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d20409fbdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619a0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3d0409fbdb391c50eb6b147a3a96197c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Management Plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

Students are required to submit a project management plan for the Honours Project covering the following elements:  executive summary describing the project to be undertaken and its scope; goals of the project; detailed project planning; resource allocation; budgeting and cost estimation; scheduling; monitoring and project control; project auditing; and project termination.

Feedback: The assignment is marked by the course coordinator using a standardised rubric.  Written feedback is given by the course coordinator and verbal feedback is given by the student's supervisor. 

The PMP is to be submitted in Term 1 of the project, the final mark will count towards both terms of MATS6114 and MATS6113.

Entrepreneurship and Commercialisation is aimed for students and professionals to gain exposure to the wide gamut of skills required to translate scientific research into commercialable reality. The entrepreneurship journey will be formalised into clear actionable steps through interaction between students and relevant leading academics and professionals. During a series of workshops, students will be guided through goal setting, customer and market segmentation, business development, and warned against common pitfalls. At the end of the course students should have the skills to improve the probability of having a successful entrepreneurial endeavour.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e1ef09bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619c9","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critical Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

This assessment task aims to assess the ability to research relevant information on business topics that may impact the commercialisation process of a product. Students will be required to locate a recent business article in a peer-reviewed journal or a reputable business publication or newspaper. They will then identify and relevant business issues discussed in the article, review them and discuss the significance of these issues in relation to the sustainability and profitability of a product recently involved in the Commercialisation Process.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e5ef09bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619c5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5def09bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619a0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Weekly Learning Activities","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

Students will be expected to participate in weekly learning activities, including online discussions and quizzes (individual, 25%),

contentlets.keywords: materials science and engineering,entrepreneurship,commercialisation,entrepreneurship and commercialisation,science entrepreneurship,science commercialisation
contentlets.description: Entrepreneurship and Commercialisation is aimed for students and professionals to gain exposure to the wide gamut of skills required to translate scientific research into commercialable reality. The entrepreneurship journey will be formalised into clear actionable steps through interaction between students and relevant leading academics and professionals. During a series of workshops, students will be guided through goal setting, customer and market segmentation, business development, and warned against common pitfalls. At the end of the course students should have the skills to improve the probability of having a successful entrepreneurial endeavour.
contentlets.title: Entrepreneurship and Commercialisation
